item.title: 1. Log Filtering
item.description: We have come from a trace to the logs for paymentservice Note that the time window is set to a specific time range that is relevant to the trace which is included in the filter Exercise Group By Severity Notice that the chart changes and you have a legend of debug, error and info Click on error, and add to filter Now only have all error fields

item.title: 2. Viewing Log Entries
item.description: Let’s quickly recap on what we have done so far using the 3 pillars of Observability: --- title: The 3 Pillars of Observability --- %%{ init:{ "theme": "neutral", "themeVariables": { "lineColor": "#ffffff" } } }%% graph LR; A["`_Metrics_ **Do I have a problem?**`"] B["`_Traces_ **Where is the problem?**`"] C["`_Logs_ **What is the problem?**`"] A --> B --> C Using metrics we identified we have a problem with our application. The error rate in the Service Dashboards was higher than it should be.

item.title: 3. Log Timeline Chart
item.description: The Log Timeline chart is a powerful tool for visualizing log messages over time. It is a great way to see the frequency of log messages and to identify patterns. It is also a great way to see the distribution of log messages across your environment. These charts can be saved to a custom dashboard (we will come on to this later in the workshop). Exercise Click on the cog to open Table Settingis, untick _raw and ensure the following are selected: k8s.

item.title: 4. Log View Chart
item.description: Exercise Repeat Log Timeline exercise for Log View chart Enter name, description, search for your dashboard Click save and goto dashboard Goto Team Dashboard Click + Add Dashboard Group Select your Dashboard Validate it appears If we had 24/7 Synthetic monitoring, we would have been alerted to this issue before our customers were impacted.
